Audio Description: The heroic images of three muscular arms reaching upwards against a fiery red background while holding tools essential in winning World War Two is dramatized in this poster issued by the United States Office of War Information in 1942. On the left, a black leather gloved-hand holds a large monkey wrench. In the center, a solider with a torn khaki uniform sleeve holds a rifle. On the right, a woman is holding an S-shaped combination wrench. Her blue sleeve with white zigzag stitching is pulled down below her elbow.   Masculine strength was a common visual theme in wartime propaganda. Images of men and machines exemplified America's ability to channel its strength into the war effort. This poster breaks slightly with tradition by including a woman. At the top of the poster is a quote by then Vice-President Henry Wallace that reads: “Strong in the sense of the Lord we who fight in the people’s cause will never stop until that cause is won.”
Creator: United States. Office of War Information
Description: Poster, 71 x 56 cm, artist: David Stone Martin
